domains.title: Snowflake AI Data Cloud Features and Architecture

questions.text: GRI wants to ensure that their Finance team's month-end reporting does not slow down the Data Science team's model training. Which Snowflake feature directly enables this?
questions.explanation: By separating storage and compute, GRI can assign different Virtual Warehouses to each team, ensuring zero resource contention.

questions.text: GRI is looking for a "zero-management" platform. Which task is GRI responsible for in Snowflake?

options.label: B
options.text: Installing software updates and security patches

questions.explanation: Snowflake is a SaaS platform; Snowflake manages infrastructure. The user is only responsible for the data and access logic.

questions.text: Which layer of the Snowflake architecture is responsible for query parsing and optimization?
questions.explanation: The Cloud Services layer is the "brain" and handles query optimization, security, and metadata.

questions.text: GRI needs to ensure that their EU data remains strictly in the EU region but needs a global view for the US HQ. Which feature supports this global architecture?
questions.explanation: Snowgrid enables cross-region replication and global data governance.

questions.text: A query is run: SELECT COUNT(\*) FROM transactions. If the warehouse is suspended, how does Snowflake return the result?

options.label: A
options.text: It fails because the warehouse is off.

options.label: B
options.text: It auto-resumes the warehouse, scans the data, and shuts down.

options.label: C
options.text: It fetches the result from the Cloud Services metadata cache without a warehouse.

options.label: D
options.text: It fetches the result from the local SSD cache of the last used warehouse.

questions.explanation: Metadata like row counts are stored in Cloud Services. No compute is required.

questions.text: GRI requires a dedicated, completely isolated Snowflake instance for their most sensitive financial data. Which edition should they choose?
questions.explanation: VPS provides a fully isolated environment for high-security requirements.

questions.text: What is the minimum billing increment for a Virtual Warehouse after the first 60 seconds?
questions.explanation: After a 1-minute minimum, billing is per-second.

questions.text: Which architectural layer is responsible for maintaining ACID compliance?
questions.explanation: Cloud Services handles transaction management and ACID compliance.

questions.text: GRI scales their Small warehouse to a Medium. This is an example of:
questions.explanation: Scaling "Up" refers to increasing the size of a single warehouse to handle more complex queries.

questions.text: A warehouse is set to "Auto-suspend: 5 minutes". It finishes a query at 12:00:00. At 12:02:00, it receives a new query. How much billing occurs for the idle time?
questions.explanation: The warehouse was active/running for those 2 minutes waiting for the next query.

questions.text: GRI wants to automate their data loading using a bash script on a Linux server. Which tool should they use?
questions.explanation: SnowSQL is the CLI tool designed for scripting and automation.

questions.text: A developer at GRI wants to build a data visualization app using Python directly inside the Snowflake UI. What should they use?
questions.explanation: Streamlit allows building interactive apps within the Snowflake environment.

questions.text: Which Snowflake tool is specifically used to diagnose if a corporate firewall is blocking access to Snowflake endpoints?
questions.explanation: SnowCD (Connectivity Diagnostic) tests network paths.

questions.text: GRI uses Tableau for business intelligence. How does Tableau connect to Snowflake?
questions.explanation: External BI tools use standard drivers like ODBC or JDBC.

questions.text: Which tool allows a data scientist to write Scala code that executes natively on Snowflake compute?
questions.explanation: Snowpark enables Python, Java, and Scala logic within Snowflake.

questions.text: What is the primary interface for managing Snowflake's account-level billing and usage charts?
questions.explanation: Snowsight is the primary web-based management interface.

questions.text: GRI wants to summarize 1,000 customer reviews using an AI model built into Snowflake. Which feature should they call?
questions.explanation: Cortex provides managed AI functions like SUMMARIZE.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a Snowflake-provided connector?
questions.explanation: Snowflake provides connectors to ingest *into* Snowflake, not for external database management.

questions.text: Can the Snowflake SQL API be used to submit DDL commands like CREATE TABLE?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it is for SELECT only.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it can execute any SQL statement.

options.label: C
options.text: No, it is for PUT and GET only.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only in the Enterprise edition.

questions.explanation: The SQL API can execute any valid Snowflake SQL.

questions.text: In Snowsight, what is the purpose of the "Query Profile"?

options.label: B
options.text: To analyze the performance and execution plan of a specific SQL query.

options.label: C
options.text: To set up MFA for a user.

questions.explanation: It provides a visual representation of how a query was processed.

questions.text: GRI has a clickstream dataset in JSON format. In which column type should they store this?
questions.explanation: VARIANT is the native data type for semi-structured data like JSON.

questions.text: GRI creates a staging table for their daily ETL process that they don't need to recover if a disaster occurs, but it must persist across different sessions. What table type should they use?
questions.explanation: Transient tables persist but have no Fail-safe, saving storage costs for non-critical data.

questions.text: A user drops a table by mistake. Which command should they use to restore it instantly?
questions.explanation: UNDROP uses Time Travel to restore dropped objects.

questions.text: Which object type allows GRI to share data with a partner without the partner seeing the underlying table names or JOIN logic?
questions.explanation: Secure Views hide the DDL and logic from unauthorized users.

questions.text: Which object is used to schedule the execution of a Stored Procedure every Monday at 8 AM?
questions.explanation: Tasks are used for scheduling SQL and procedures.

questions.text: A "Managed Access Schema" is different from a "Standard Schema" because:

options.label: A
options.text: It is only available in Business Critical edition.

options.label: B
options.text: The object owner cannot grant privileges; only the schema owner can.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not allow the creation of views.

questions.explanation: Managed schemas centralize grant management to the schema owner.

questions.text: GRI wants to track exactly which rows in a table have changed since the last time their ETL process ran. Which object should they use?
questions.explanation: Streams track DML changes (inserts, updates, deletes) on a table.

questions.text: What is the maximum size of a single VARIANT column value?
questions.explanation: VARIANT columns are capped at 16 MB.

questions.text: Which object is used to connect an External Stage to a target table for continuous, automated data loading?
questions.explanation: A Pipe (Snowpipe) automates the COPY INTO command.

questions.text: GRI wants to provide a unique ID to every row in a table automatically. Which object should they use?
questions.explanation: Sequences generate unique numerical values.

questions.text: How are micro-partitions created in Snowflake?

options.label: A
options.text: Manually by the user using the PARTITION BY clause.

options.label: B
options.text: Automatically by Snowflake during the data load process.

options.label: C
options.text: By setting a "Partitioning Key" on the table.

options.label: D
options.text: Only when using the Enterprise edition.

questions.explanation: Snowflake automatically and transparently micro-partitions all data.

questions.text: A query scans a table with 1,000 micro-partitions but only reads 5 of them based on a date filter. This is known as:
questions.explanation: Pruning uses metadata to skip irrelevant micro-partitions.

questions.text: GRI has a 500 TB table where queries by 'Store\_ID' are very slow. What should they consider?

options.label: C
options.text: Moving the data to a Transient table.

questions.explanation: Clustering keys reorganize data to improve pruning on specific columns for massive tables.

questions.text: Where is micro-partition metadata (like Min/Max values) stored?
questions.explanation: Metadata is stored and managed in the Cloud Services layer.

questions.text: When data in a micro-partition is "updated," what happens?

options.label: A
options.text: The existing micro-partition is modified on disk.

options.label: B
options.text: The micro-partition is deleted and a new one is created.

options.label: C
options.text: The micro-partition is marked as "dirty" and new data is added to a new micro-partition.

options.label: D
options.text: Updates are stored in the Result Cache.

questions.explanation: Micro-partitions are immutable. Updates result in new micro-partitions being written (enabling Time Travel).

questions.text: Which view provides the most up-to-date storage metrics for a specific table?
questions.explanation: Information Schema is real-time; Account Usage has a latency of up to 2 hours.

questions.text: Data "Clustering" in Snowflake is:

options.label: A
options.text: A manual process that requires shutting down the warehouse.

options.label: B
options.text: A background service that re-sorts data to improve pruning.

options.label: D
options.text: Used to move data between regions.

questions.explanation: Automatic clustering is a serverless background service.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT contribute to storage costs in Snowflake?
questions.explanation: Caching does not incur storage fees; only table data (Active, Time Travel, Fail-safe) does.

questions.text: What is the typical size of a micro-partition before compression?
questions.explanation: Micro-partitions range from 50MB to 500MB of uncompressed data.

questions.text: A table is naturally clustered by 'Date'. If data is loaded randomly by date, what happens to pruning performance?

options.label: B
options.text: It degrades, and a Clustering Key may be needed.

options.label: D
options.text: The Cloud Services layer fixes it instantly for free.

questions.explanation: Natural clustering depends on load order. Random loading degrades pruning performance.

questions.text: GRI wants to ensure that the ACCOUNTADMIN role can only be accessed from the corporate headquarters' IP range. Which feature should they use?

options.label: B
options.text: Network Policy applied at the Account level

options.label: C
options.text: Network Policy applied at the User level

questions.explanation: While an account-level policy affects everyone, applying a specific Network Policy to a user (or the user holding the ACCOUNTADMIN role) allows for stricter overrides for sensitive access.

questions.text: Which protocol does Snowflake use to support Federated Authentication and Single Sign-On (SSO)?
questions.explanation: Snowflake specifically uses SAML 2.0 for federated authentication with Identity Providers (IdP).

questions.text: GRI is setting up an automated Python script to load data every night. The script cannot interact with a web browser for MFA. What is the recommended authentication method?

options.label: A
options.text: Username and Password in the script

questions.explanation: Key Pair Authentication is the best practice for service accounts and automated tools that don't support interactive login.

questions.text: A GRI employee is prompted for a Duo Mobile push notification when logging in. Which feature is being utilized?
questions.explanation: Snowflake’s built-in MFA is powered by Duo Security.

questions.text: When a Network Policy is applied at both the Account level and the User level, which one takes precedence?

options.label: C
options.text: Both are combined (the most restrictive applies)

options.label: D
options.text: Neither; they conflict and cause an error

questions.explanation: User-level network policies always override Account-level policies.

questions.text: GRI wants to disable the ability for users to use a password and force them to use Okta for all logins. What must they configure?

options.label: A
options.text: A Network Policy blocking all IPs

options.label: C
options.text: Advanced SAML configuration with the SAML\_IDENTITY\_PROVIDER parameter

options.label: D
options.text: Use the SECURITYADMIN role to delete all passwords

questions.explanation: Configuring Federated Auth/SSO via SAML allows the organization to manage authentication through their IdP.

questions.text: Can a Snowflake user have more than one public key assigned for Key Pair Authentication?

options.label: A
options.text: No, only one key is allowed per user.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, up to two public keys (RSA\_PUBLIC\_KEY and RSA\_PUBLIC\_KEY\_2).

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, up to ten public keys.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they have the ACCOUNTADMIN role.

questions.explanation: Snowflake allows two keys to facilitate key rotation without downtime.

questions.text: An admin at GRI creates a Network Policy but forgets to add their own IP to the "Allowed" list before applying it to the account. What happens?

options.label: A
options.text: Snowflake automatically adds the admin's current IP.

options.label: B
options.text: The admin is locked out, and only Snowflake Support can fix it.

options.label: C
options.text: Snowflake blocks the action and issues an error message.

options.label: D
options.text: The policy is created but not activated.

questions.explanation: Snowflake includes a safety check; it will not let you apply a policy that blocks your own current connection.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of using Federated Authentication?

options.label: A
options.text: Users only have to remember one password.

options.label: B
options.text: Snowflake manages the user's password complexity rules.

options.label: C
options.text: Terminated employees lose access to Snowflake immediately when deactivated in the IdP.

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced administrative overhead for managing user credentials in Snowflake.

questions.explanation: In Federated Auth, the Identity Provider (IdP) manages the password rules, not Snowflake.

questions.text: GRI wants to use a 3rd party tool (like a Data Catalog) that needs to access Snowflake metadata but shouldn't have a permanent password. Which method is most secure?
questions.explanation: OAuth allows 3rd party applications to access Snowflake via tokens without sharing user credentials.

questions.text: GRI’s CFO needs to view billing statements and manage credit usage across all accounts in the organization. Which role should they be granted?
questions.explanation: ORGADMIN is the organizational-level role for managing accounts and viewing multi-account billing.

questions.text: A new developer needs to create a new Database and a Virtual Warehouse. Which system role is primarily responsible for this?
questions.explanation: SYSADMIN is the role intended for creating and managing all "functional" objects like warehouses and databases.

questions.text: GRI uses a custom role called SALES\_ANALYST. They want to ensure that SYSADMIN can manage the tables created by this role. How should they set this up?

options.label: A
options.text: Grant SYSADMIN to the SALES\_ANALYST role.

options.label: B
options.text: Grant the SALES\_ANALYST role to SYSADMIN.

options.label: D
options.text: This happens automatically and requires no setup.

questions.explanation: In the role hierarchy, granting a lower role to a higher role allows the higher role to inherit all permissions.

questions.text: Which role is the only one that can manage the ORGADMIN role?
questions.explanation: Only a user with the ORGADMIN role can grant the ORGADMIN role to other users.

questions.text: A user at GRI has been granted both ANALYST and DEVELOPER roles. When they log in, which permissions do they have?

options.label: B
options.text: Only the permissions of the PUBLIC role until they switch roles.

options.label: C
options.text: Only the permissions of their "Primary Role" designated in their user profile.

options.label: D
options.text: No permissions until they use the USE ROLE command.

questions.explanation: Every user has a default/primary role. While they can switch, their session starts with that primary role.

questions.text: Who is the "Owner" of an object in Snowflake's Discretionary Access Control (DAC) model?

options.label: A
options.text: The user who created the object.

options.label: C
options.text: The role that was active when the object was created.

questions.explanation: Ownership is tied to a **Role**, not a User.

questions.text: GRI wants to prevent a data engineer from granting access to their own tables and instead have a central admin manage all grants. What should they implement?
questions.explanation: In a Managed Access Schema, object owners lose the ability to grant permissions; it is centralized to the schema owner.

questions.text: Which system role is best suited for creating and dropping users and roles, but should NOT have access to query business data?
questions.explanation: USERADMIN is dedicated to user and role management to help separate concerns.

questions.text: If a role is revoked from a user while they are in an active session using that role, what happens?

options.label: B
options.text: The user can continue using the role until the session ends or they switch roles.

options.label: C
options.text: The user is downgraded to the PUBLIC role immediately.

questions.explanation: Revocations do not affect currently active sessions; they apply to the next session or role switch.

questions.text: The SECURITYADMIN role inherits the privileges of which other role?
questions.explanation: SECURITYADMIN is a parent to USERADMIN in the default system hierarchy.

questions.text: GRI needs to hide the first 12 digits of customer credit card numbers for all roles except BILLING\_ADMIN. Which feature should they use?
questions.explanation: Dynamic Data Masking is a column-level security feature used to mask sensitive data.

questions.text: A manager at GRI should only see sales records from the "North" region. Which feature should be used to enforce this?
questions.explanation: Row Access Policies filter which rows are returned based on the user's role or attributes.

questions.text: GRI wants to track which users have queried a specific table containing PII over the last 6 months. Where can they find this?
questions.explanation: ACCESS\_HISTORY specifically tracks which columns and tables were accessed by users.

questions.text: Which view allows an admin to see a list of all tables in the database that are tagged as "High Sensitivity"?
questions.explanation: TAG\_REFERENCES allows you to track where tags are applied across the account.

questions.text: When sharing a view with an external partner, why should GRI use a "Secure View"?

options.label: A
options.text: To encrypt the data during transit.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the partner from seeing the underlying table names and JOIN logic via GET\_DDL.

options.label: D
options.text: To improve the query performance for the partner.

questions.explanation: Secure views prevent users from viewing the definition of the view or using optimizations that might leak data patterns.

questions.text: What is the maximum number of days of historical data available in the ACCOUNT\_USAGE schema?
questions.explanation: ACCOUNT\_USAGE views retain data for up to 1 year.

questions.text: GRI wants to automatically apply a masking policy to any column that is tagged with the string 'PII'. This is called:
questions.explanation: Tag-Based Masking allows policies to be applied automatically to any object carrying a specific tag.

questions.text: Which of the following describes "Data Lineage" in Snowflake?

options.label: A
options.text: The history of which users logged into the account.

options.label: B
options.text: The path of how data flowed from source objects to target objects.

options.label: C
options.text: The geographical location where data is stored.

options.label: D
options.text: The list of versions of a stored procedure.

questions.explanation: Access History and Object Dependencies help define data lineage.

questions.text: Which schema contains real-time metadata but has no historical retention beyond currently existing objects?
questions.explanation: INFORMATION\_SCHEMA provides a real-time view of current objects.

questions.text: Can a masking policy be applied to a column that is part of a Cluster Key?

options.label: B
options.text: No, Snowflake does not allow masking on columns used for clustering.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if the table is a Transient table.

questions.explanation: Masking policies cannot be applied to columns used as clustering keys.

subTopics.title: Explain the use of the Query Profile

questions.text: An analyst at GRI notices a query is running significantly slower than usual. Upon checking the Query Profile, they see "Remote Disk Spilling." What does this indicate?

options.label: B
options.text: The warehouse ran out of memory (RAM) and local SSD, and had to use slower cloud storage.

options.label: C
options.text: The result was fetched from the Result Cache.

options.label: D
options.text: There is a network issue between the warehouse and the database.

questions.explanation: Remote spilling is the slowest form of data processing and indicates the warehouse size is too small for the query's memory requirements.

questions.text: In the Query Profile, what does the "Partitions Scanned" vs "Partitions Total" metric help you evaluate?
questions.explanation: If a query scans many partitions but returns few rows, pruning is inefficient, possibly suggesting a need for a clustering key.

questions.text: GRI wants to see why a query from 3 days ago was slow. Where can they find the Query Profile for historical queries?

options.label: B
options.text: In the Query History page of Snowsight.

options.label: D
options.text: It is deleted immediately after the query finishes.

questions.explanation: Snowsight maintains the visual Query Profile for queries run within the last 14 days.

questions.text: If a Query Profile shows that 80% of the time was spent in "Query Compilation," what is likely the cause?

options.label: B
options.text: Highly complex SQL with many joins or nested views.

questions.explanation: Compilation happens in the Cloud Services layer and is driven by query complexity, not data volume.

questions.text: Which operator in the Query Profile tree represents the final step where data is sent back to the user?
questions.explanation: The Result operator represents the final output of the query.

questions.text: A GRI admin sees "Local Disk Spilling" in a profile. What is the immediate recommendation?
questions.explanation: Local spilling occurs when RAM is exhausted. Scaling up provides more RAM per node.

questions.text: The Query Profile shows "Metadata Only" for a specific query. This means:

options.label: B
options.text: The query was answered entirely by the Cloud Services layer without a warehouse.

options.label: C
options.text: The warehouse was too small to read the data.

options.label: D
options.text: The user doesn't have permissions to see the data.

questions.explanation: Simple metadata queries (like COUNT(\*)) don't require compute.

questions.text: If the "Exploding Joins" warning appears in the Query Profile, what is happening?

options.label: B
options.text: The join is producing significantly more rows than the input tables (likely a Cartesian product).

options.label: C
options.text: The query is too fast for the profile to track.

questions.explanation: Exploding joins indicate a logic error in the SQL JOIN condition.

questions.text: Which metric in the Query Profile indicates how much data was sent over the network between warehouse nodes?
questions.explanation: This helps identify if data shuffling between nodes is causing a bottleneck.

questions.text: Can you compare two query profiles side-by-side in Snowflake?

options.label: A
options.text: No, only one at a time.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, by selecting multiple queries in Query History and choosing "Compare."

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only in the Business Critical edition.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they were run by the same user.

questions.explanation: Snowsight allows comparing execution plans to see why performance differs.

questions.text: GRI's BI dashboard is used by 500 people simultaneously. Queries are queuing. What should they do?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the warehouse size from Small to Large.

options.label: B
options.text: Enable a Multi-cluster warehouse and set it to Auto-scale.

questions.explanation: Multi-cluster warehouses solve concurrency (queuing) by scaling "Out."

questions.text: A warehouse is configured with MIN\_CLUSTER\_COUNT \= 2 and MAX\_CLUSTER\_COUNT \= 2. What mode is this?
questions.explanation: When Min and Max are equal, the warehouse is in Maximized mode.

questions.text: In "Economy" scaling policy, when does Snowflake start a new cluster?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately when a query is queued.

options.label: B
options.text: Only if there is enough load to keep the cluster busy for at least 6 minutes.

options.label: C
options.text: When the first cluster reaches 50% capacity.

questions.explanation: Economy policy prioritizes cost savings over immediate performance.

questions.text: GRI scales their warehouse from X-Small to Small. How much does the credit cost per hour change?
questions.explanation: Credit costs double with each T-shirt size increase.

questions.text: Which setting prevents a single user from running a query that consumes credits for 24 hours straight?
questions.explanation: This parameter kills queries that exceed a specific time limit.

questions.text: A warehouse is set to AUTO\_SUSPEND \= 60. A query finishes at 10:00:00. No other queries arrive. When does it stop charging credits?

options.label: D
options.text: It never stops unless manually suspended.

questions.explanation: It suspends after 60 seconds of inactivity.

questions.text: GRI wants to ensure that a warehouse is always available for a high-priority CEO dashboard. Which setting is most critical?
questions.explanation: Auto-resume ensures the warehouse wakes up as soon as the CEO opens the dashboard.

questions.text: Can a Virtual Warehouse be resized while it is actively running queries?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it must be suspended first.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, and the new size applies to all currently running queries.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but the new size only applies to *new* queries submitted after the change.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if it is a Multi-cluster warehouse.

questions.explanation: Resizing is dynamic but doesn't affect queries already in progress.

questions.text: Which role is required to change the size of a warehouse?

options.label: A
options.text: Any user with USAGE on the warehouse.

options.label: C
options.text: A role with the MODIFY privilege on the warehouse.

questions.explanation: MODIFY (or OWNERSHIP) is required to alter warehouse parameters.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between a "Standard" and "Snowpark-Optimized" warehouse?

options.label: B
options.text: Snowpark-Optimized has 16x more memory (RAM) per node.

options.label: D
options.text: Snowpark-Optimized is free for the first hour.

questions.explanation: Snowpark-Optimized warehouses are designed for memory-intensive ML workloads.

questions.text: Which feature allows Snowflake to automatically offload parts of a query to a serverless pool of compute to speed it up?
questions.explanation: QAS acts like an "extra boost" for specific query types without resizing the warehouse.

questions.text: GRI notices that a specific warehouse has a "Load Monitoring" chart showing a consistent red bar (Queued queries). What is the recommended action to improve concurrency?
questions.explanation: Queuing is a sign that there aren't enough clusters to handle the volume of queries.

questions.text: Does the Query Acceleration Service (QAS) cost additional credits?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it is included in the warehouse price.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it is billed as a serverless cost.

options.label: C
options.text: Only in the Business Critical edition.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if the query takes longer than 10 minutes.

questions.explanation: QAS is a serverless feature billed based on usage.

questions.text: When comparing "Scaling Up" vs "Scaling Out," which one is better for a single query that processes 100TB of data?
questions.explanation: Scaling "Up" (larger size) gives that single query more resources to finish faster.

questions.text: Which view in the SNOWFLAKE database helps GRI monitor warehouse load history over the last year?
questions.explanation: This view provides average running and queued queries over time.

questions.text: What is the maximum number of clusters a Multi-cluster warehouse can have?
questions.explanation: The default limit is 10 clusters.

questions.text: A query is eligible for QAS. How can a user verify if QAS actually helped the query?

options.label: A
options.text: By looking at the Query Profile "Query Acceleration" stats.

questions.explanation: The profile shows how many partitions were offloaded to the service.

questions.text: GRI wants to optimize their "Standard" scaling policy to be more aggressive in shutting down idle clusters. What should they do?
questions.explanation: Economy policy is more conservative about starting clusters and more aggressive about stopping them.

questions.text: If a warehouse is resized from Large to Small while a Large query is running, what size does the running query use?

options.label: B
options.text: It continues running on the Large resources until finished.

options.label: C
options.text: It is throttled to Small speed instantly.

options.label: D
options.text: It restarts automatically on the Small warehouse.

questions.explanation: Running queries are not interrupted by resizing operations.

questions.text: Which tool would you use to find the "peak" concurrency hour for your Snowflake account?
questions.explanation: The load monitoring charts show concurrency spikes visually.

questions.text: A user runs SELECT \* FROM table twice within 5 minutes. The second time is instant. Which cache was used?
questions.explanation: Result cache stores query results for 24 hours.

questions.text: Under what condition is the Result Cache purged or bypassed?

options.label: B
options.text: If the underlying data in the table changes.

options.label: C
options.text: If the user changes their active role (sometimes).

questions.explanation: Result cache is very sensitive to data and context changes.

questions.text: GRI has a table with 1 Billion rows. They frequently run queries like WHERE User\_Email \= 'abc@xyz.com'. What optimization is best?
questions.explanation: SOS is specifically for "point lookups" (finding specific values in large tables).

questions.text: What is a major limitation of Materialized Views in Snowflake?

options.label: B
options.text: They only work on a single table (no joins allowed in the definition).

questions.explanation: Snowflake Materialized Views currently do not support JOINS in their definition.

questions.text: A warehouse is suspended. Which cache is immediately lost?
questions.explanation: The local SSD cache is tied to the running compute nodes.

questions.text: GRI uses a Clustering Key on their Sales table. What background service maintains this clustering?
questions.explanation: Automatic Clustering is a serverless maintenance service.

questions.text: How can a user "force" Snowflake to bypass the Result Cache for testing purposes?

options.label: D
options.text: Log out and log back in.

questions.explanation: This session parameter disables the result cache.

questions.text: Which optimization technique uses "shredding" to improve performance on VARIANT (JSON) columns?
questions.explanation: Snowflake automatically optimizes JSON storage to make querying as fast as relational data.

questions.text: When should GRI use a "Materialized View" instead of a "Standard View"?

options.label: A
options.text: When the query is simple and runs fast.

options.label: B
options.text: When the query involves complex aggregations and the results are needed frequently.

options.label: C
options.text: When they want to hide SQL logic.

options.label: D
options.text: When they want to avoid storage costs.

questions.explanation: MVs trade storage and maintenance costs for significantly faster query speeds.

questions.text: Does "Search Optimization" require a warehouse to be running to serve results?

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, the query still runs on a Virtual Warehouse, but it uses the SOS index to prune data.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if the table is larger than 10TB.

questions.explanation: SOS helps the warehouse prune data; it doesn't replace the warehouse.

questions.text: GRI wants to be notified when their "Dev\_WH" consumes more than 500 credits. Which feature should they use?
questions.explanation: Resource monitors are the primary tool for setting credit quotas and alerts.

questions.text: A Resource Monitor is set to "Suspend Immediately" at 100%. What happens to queries currently running when the limit is hit?

options.label: C
options.text: They are moved to another warehouse.

options.label: D
options.text: They are paused and resumed next month.

questions.explanation: "Suspend Immediately" kills all active queries.

questions.text: Which Snowflake cost represents the "Average daily storage" across the month?
questions.explanation: Storage is billed based on average monthly usage in Terabytes.

questions.text: GRI sees a charge for "Cloud Services" on their bill. Under what rule are they charged for this?

options.label: A
options.text: It is always 10% of the bill.

options.label: B
options.text: They are only charged if Cloud Services usage exceeds 10% of their total daily compute.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a flat fee of $100/month.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if they use the ORGADMIN role.

questions.explanation: Snowflake provides a 10% credit for cloud services.

questions.text: Which view provides a 365-day history of every credit spent by every warehouse in the account?
questions.explanation: ACCOUNT\_USAGE contains the 1-year historical view.

questions.text: GRI wants to assign costs to the "Marketing" department. How should they label their warehouses?

options.label: C
options.text: By creating a separate Snowflake account for Marketing.

questions.explanation: Tagging objects is the best practice for cost attribution and reporting.

questions.text: Does "Fail-safe" storage incur a cost?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it is a free service provided by Snowflake.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it is billed at the same rate as standard storage.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if you actually recover data from it.

questions.explanation: Data in Fail-safe contributes to your total monthly storage bill.

questions.text: Which of the following is a "Serverless" cost in Snowflake?

options.label: C
options.text: Data transfer to another cloud region

questions.explanation: Snowpipe, Automatic Clustering, and MV maintenance are serverless costs.

questions.text: GRI wants to prevent an accidental "infinite loop" query from costing $10,000. What is the best safety measure?

options.label: A
options.text: Set a STATEMENT\_TIMEOUT\_IN\_SECONDS at the account or warehouse level.

questions.explanation: This ensures queries are killed after a reasonable amount of time.

questions.text: A Snowflake "Budget" (the specific feature) can monitor:

options.label: C
options.text: A custom group of Snowflake objects (Warehouses, Pipes, MVs, etc.).

questions.explanation: Budgets are flexible and can track groups of objects to alert on total spend.

questions.text: GRI wants to load data from an AWS S3 bucket. Which type of stage is required?
questions.explanation: External stages point to cloud storage locations (S3, GCS, Azure) outside of Snowflake.

questions.text: A data engineer at GRI is loading files that are 2 GB each. What is the Snowflake best practice for optimal load performance?

options.label: A
options.text: Load them as-is to save time on splitting.

options.label: B
options.text: Split the files into 100-250 MB compressed chunks.

options.label: C
options.text: Convert the files to a single large JSON VARIANT.

options.label: D
options.text: Use a 4XL warehouse to process the large file.

questions.explanation: Snowflake processes data in parallel; smaller, balanced files allow multiple threads to work simultaneously.

questions.text: GRI's web app sends sales data every minute. Which feature provides the most cost-effective, near real-time ingestion?

options.label: A
options.text: Bulk loading with COPY INTO every minute.

options.label: C
options.text: INSERT INTO statements for every sale.

questions.explanation: Snowpipe is designed for continuous, near real-time ingestion using serverless compute.

questions.text: Which internal stage is automatically available to every user and does not need to be created?
questions.explanation: The User Stage (@\~) is unique to each user and created automatically.

questions.text: When loading data, which architectural layer handles the "metadata" about which files have already been loaded to prevent duplication?
questions.explanation: Cloud Services manages load metadata (load history) to prevent re-loading the same file.

questions.text: GRI wants to load data from S3 without providing secret keys in every SQL command. What object should they use to store credentials securely?
questions.explanation: A Storage Integration object allows Snowflake to access cloud storage via IAM roles instead of credentials.

questions.text: A warehouse is suspended. Can Snowpipe still load data?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it requires an active warehouse.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it uses Snowflake-managed serverless compute.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if it is the Standard edition.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if the AUTO\_RESUME setting is on.

questions.explanation: Snowpipe is a serverless feature and does not depend on the user's Virtual Warehouses.

questions.text: GRI organizes their S3 bucket by date: /logs/2024/01/01/. How does this help Snowflake?

options.label: A
options.text: It doesn't; Snowflake ignores folder structures.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for "path-based" loading to limit the number of files scanned in a COPY command.

options.label: C
options.text: It automatically clusters the table by date.

questions.explanation: Using paths (prefixes) allows Snowflake to efficiently filter files during the load process.

questions.text: Which file format is NOT natively supported for direct loading into Snowflake?
questions.explanation: Snowflake supports CSV, JSON, XML, Avro, Parquet, and ORC.

questions.text: Does Snowflake automatically detect the compression type of a file during the load process?

options.label: A
options.text: No, you must specify it in the FILE\_FORMAT.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, for supported types like GZIP, BZIP2, and ZSTD.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if using an External Stage.

questions.explanation: Snowflake can auto-detect compression for most standard formats.

questions.text: A regional manager wants to upload a CSV from their laptop to a Snowflake internal stage. Which command must they use?
questions.explanation: PUT is used to upload local files to Snowflake internal stages.

questions.text: GRI wants to load data from a stage but needs to skip the first column and convert the second column to uppercase. Can they do this in a single command?

options.label: A
options.text: No, they must load to a staging table first.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, using a transformation inside the COPY INTO statement.

questions.explanation: COPY INTO supports basic transformations like column reordering and simple functions.

questions.text: Which command is used to troubleshoot and view rows that failed to load during a COPY INTO operation?
questions.explanation: VALIDATE allows you to inspect the errors of a previous load.

questions.text: GRI wants to query a large set of log files in S3 without actually importing the data into Snowflake tables. What should they create?
questions.explanation: External tables allow querying files directly in cloud storage.

questions.text: Which parameter in the COPY INTO command ensures that the file is deleted from the stage after a successful load?
questions.explanation: PURGE \= TRUE removes files from the stage upon successful completion.

questions.text: A user attempts to run a PUT command in the Snowsight SQL Worksheet. What happens?

options.label: A
options.text: The file is uploaded to the user stage.

options.label: B
options.text: It fails; PUT and GET are not supported in the web UI.

options.label: C
options.text: It succeeds only for files under 50 MB.

questions.explanation: PUT and GET must be executed via SnowSQL (CLI) or drivers.

questions.text: What is the default behavior of COPY INTO if it encounters a single error in a file?

options.label: A
options.text: It skips the bad row and continues.

options.label: B
options.text: It aborts the entire load operation (ABORT\_STATEMENT).

options.label: C
options.text: It loads the bad row as a NULL.

questions.explanation: The default ON\_ERROR value is ABORT\_STATEMENT.

questions.text: Which object stores the definition of a CSV's delimiter, header count, and escape characters for reuse?
questions.explanation: File Formats are reusable objects for parsing rules.

questions.text: GRI needs to reload a file that was loaded 20 days ago. The file is still in the stage. By default, what will COPY INTO do?

options.label: B
options.text: Skip it because it is in the load history.

questions.explanation: Snowflake tracks load history for 64 days and skips previously loaded files unless FORCE \= TRUE is used.

questions.text: Which command defines the automated ingestion logic used by Snowpipe?
questions.explanation: CREATE PIPE defines the COPY INTO logic for Snowpipe.

questions.text: GRI is unloading a 10 TB table. By default, how many files will Snowflake create?

options.label: C
options.text: Multiple files, to utilize parallel execution.

options.label: D
options.text: None; unloading is a single-threaded process.

questions.explanation: Snowflake unloads data in parallel, creating multiple files for performance.

questions.text: Which compression format is applied by default when unloading data from Snowflake?
questions.explanation: GZIP is the default compression for unloading.

questions.text: GRI needs to export data to a partner who can only process a single large file. Which parameter should they use in COPY INTO \<location\>?
questions.explanation: SINGLE \= TRUE forces Snowflake to output a single file.

questions.text: When unloading a table to a CSV, how are NULL values represented in the file by default?
questions.explanation: By default, NULL values are unloaded as empty strings.

questions.text: GRI wants to unload relational data into a JSON file format. Which function helps convert rows into JSON objects during the unload?
questions.explanation: OBJECT\_CONSTRUCT builds a JSON object from relational columns.

questions.text: Is it possible to unload data directly to a local hard drive from the Snowsight UI?

options.label: B
options.text: No, you must unload to a stage first, then use GET.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if using the SYSADMIN role.

questions.explanation: The COPY INTO \<location\> command requires a stage.

questions.text: GRI wants to ensure that unloaded files do not exceed 500 MB. Which parameter should they set?
questions.explanation: MAX\_FILE\_SIZE defines the upper limit for each unloaded file.

questions.text: Which column property is NOT preserved when unloading data to a CSV file?
questions.explanation: CSV files are plain text; they do not store metadata like data types or constraints.

questions.text: Can a user unload data from a View?

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, the COPY INTO \<location\> command accepts a SELECT statement.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if it is a Materialized View.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if the view is in the PUBLIC schema.

questions.explanation: You can unload the results of any query, including those from a view.

questions.text: GRI wants to overwrite files in the stage that have the same name as the new unloaded files. Which parameter is needed?
questions.explanation: OVERWRITE \= TRUE allows the unload to replace existing files in the stage.

questions.text: Which command is used to move files from a Snowflake Internal Stage to a local folder?
questions.explanation: GET is used to download files from internal stages.

questions.text: GRI wants to verify the size and count of files they just unloaded into @my\_stage. Which command should they use?
questions.explanation: LIST (or LS) shows the files in a stage.

questions.text: Does the GET command support downloading files from an External Stage (e.g., S3)?

options.label: B
options.text: No, GET only works with Internal Stages.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if the Storage Integration is configured.

questions.explanation: GET is restricted to Snowflake internal storage.

questions.text: Which command is used to export data from a Snowflake table to an external cloud bucket?
questions.explanation: COPY INTO \<location\> is the command for unloading.

questions.text: When using LIST @stage, what information is provided?

options.label: A
options.text: File name, size, MD5 hash, and last modified date.

options.label: C
options.text: The users who accessed the files.

options.label: D
options.text: The SQL command that created the files.

questions.explanation: LIST provides metadata about the files in the stage.

questions.text: GRI is using SnowSQL. They want to download all files from a stage that end in .csv. What syntax should they use?
questions.explanation: GET (and PUT) support regex patterns for file selection.

questions.text: Which role is required to execute a GET command on a Named Internal Stage?

options.label: A
options.text: Any role with the USAGE privilege on the stage.

options.label: C
options.text: Only the user who created the stage.

questions.explanation: USAGE (or READ depending on version/setting) is required to access files in a stage.

questions.text: Can the LIST command filter results to show only files in a specific sub-folder of a stage?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it always shows the whole stage.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, by specifying the path (e.g., LIST @my\_stage/folder1/).

options.label: C
options.text: Only if the stage is an External Stage.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if using the SECURITYADMIN role.

questions.explanation: You can specify paths in the LIST command.

questions.text: GRI unloads data to an internal stage using COPY INTO @\~. Where does the data go?
questions.explanation: @\~ denotes the User Stage.

questions.text: A user unloads data to a stage and then runs a GET command. They notice the file name in the local folder has an additional .gz extension. Why?

options.label: B
options.text: The GET command compresses data during the download.

options.label: C
options.text: Snowflake compresses unloaded files by default (GZIP).

options.label: D
options.text: The user's operating system added it.

questions.explanation: Unloading defaults to GZIP compression.

questions.text: GRI needs to find the approximate number of unique customers who visited their site across 5 billion rows. Which function provides the fastest result with minimal compute?
questions.explanation: APPROX\_COUNT\_DISTINCT uses the HyperLogLog algorithm to provide a fast estimate, avoiding the heavy compute required for an exact count on massive datasets.

questions.text: GRI wants to test a new machine learning model on exactly 10% of their 100 TB Transactions table. Which sampling method is most efficient for a table of this size?
questions.explanation: System (Block) sampling selects micro-partitions rather than individual rows, making it significantly faster for massive tables, though less "random" at the row level.

questions.text: A developer at GRI writes a function in SQL that calculates a tax rate and returns a single decimal value. This is an example of a:
questions.explanation: A Scalar User-Defined Function (UDF) returns exactly one value for each input row.

questions.text: GRI wants to use a 3rd-party sentiment analysis API to process customer comments stored in Snowflake. Which feature allows Snowflake to send data to an external API and receive the result?
questions.explanation: External functions allow Snowflake to call services outside the platform, such as AWS Lambda or Azure Functions.

questions.text: What is the main difference between a Stored Procedure and a UDF in Snowflake?

options.label: A
options.text: Procedures are only in JavaScript; UDFs are only in SQL.

options.label: B
options.text: Procedures are called using CALL to perform actions; UDFs are used in SELECT statements to calculate values.

options.label: C
options.text: Procedures return tables; UDFs return single values.

options.label: D
options.text: UDFs can modify the database; Procedures cannot.

questions.explanation: Procedures are for procedural logic and administrative tasks (invoked with CALL), whereas UDFs are for data transformation within a query.

questions.text: GRI wants to process only the "New" records that have been added to the Orders table since the last ETL run. Which object acts as a Change Data Capture (CDC) mechanism?
questions.explanation: Streams track DML changes (inserts, updates, deletes) on a table so that only delta data can be processed.

questions.text: A GRI task is scheduled to run every 5 minutes. However, the engineers don't want to waste credits if there is no new data. What is the best practice?

options.label: B
options.text: Use WHEN SYSTEM$STREAM\_HAS\_DATA('my\_stream') in the task definition.

questions.explanation: The WHEN clause allows a task to check if a stream contains data before starting the warehouse.

questions.text: Can a Snowflake Task be configured to trigger based on a message from an external queue like AWS SQS?

options.label: B
options.text: No, tasks can only be scheduled by time (Cron/Interval) or as a child of another task.

options.label: C
options.text: Only in the Business Critical edition.

questions.explanation: Tasks are currently time-based or dependency-based (DAGs); they are not natively triggered by external events.

questions.text: GRI has a "Task Tree" (DAG). If the Parent Task fails, what happens to the Child Task?

options.label: C
options.text: it retries the Parent Task automatically.

questions.explanation: By default, child tasks only execute if the predecessor task completes successfully.

questions.text: A "Standard" stream on a table tracks which of the following?
questions.explanation: A standard stream tracks all DML changes, including the "before" and "after" state of updated rows.

questions.text: GRI stores mobile app logs in a VARIANT column. What is the maximum size allowed for a single row in this column?
questions.explanation: The VARIANT data type has a limit of 16 MB per row.

questions.text: Which character is used in Snowflake SQL to navigate through nested keys in a JSON object stored in a VARIANT column?
questions.explanation: The colon (:) is used to traverse semi-structured data (e.g., column\_name:key\_name).

questions.text: GRI's JSON data contains an array of items: {"items": \[1, 2, 3\]}. Which function should they use to turn these 3 array elements into 3 separate rows?
questions.explanation: The FLATTEN table function explodes compound values (arrays/objects) into multiple rows.

questions.text: When using FLATTEN, which clause is commonly used to join the exploded rows back to the original source row?
questions.explanation: LATERAL FLATTEN is the standard pattern for joining flattened data with the parent record.

questions.text: GRI wants to convert a JSON string value "123.45" from a VARIANT column into an actual numeric type for a calculation. What is the correct syntax?
questions.explanation: Both CAST and the double-colon :: notation are valid for casting semi-structured data.

questions.text: Does Snowflake automatically optimize the storage of semi-structured data (like Parquet or JSON) for better performance?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it is stored as a raw blob.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it "shreds" common paths into hidden columns for faster access.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if the table is Clustered.

questions.explanation: Snowflake performs automatic internal optimizations on VARIANT data to achieve performance similar to relational data.

questions.text: Which function returns a JSON object created from multiple relational columns?
questions.explanation: OBJECT\_CONSTRUCT takes key-value pairs or column names and builds a JSON object.

questions.text: GRI is querying a VARIANT column and receives a value enclosed in double quotes: "Active". They want the raw string Active. What should they do?

options.label: B
options.text: Cast the value to a string (e.g., ::string).

questions.explanation: Casting a VARIANT value to a string removes the JSON quotes.

questions.text: If a GRI analyst queries a key that does not exist in a JSON object, what does Snowflake return?
questions.explanation: If a path/key does not exist, Snowflake returns a SQL NULL.

questions.text: Which semi-structured format is NOT supported for direct loading into a VARIANT column?
questions.explanation: CSV is a structured format. While you can load it, it doesn't go into a VARIANT column in its raw form like JSON or XML.

questions.text: GRI has thousands of PDF invoices in an S3 bucket. Which object allows them to see the file names, sizes, and metadata of these files inside Snowflake?
questions.explanation: A Directory Table is a catalog of files in a stage (internal or external).

questions.text: GRI wants to generate a temporary link to a PDF file that a user can click on to view the document without logging into Snowflake. Which URL type should they use?
questions.explanation: Scoped URLs are temporary, encoded links that allow access without a Snowflake login for a short duration.

questions.text: Which URL type is permanent and does not expire, but requires the user to be authenticated into Snowflake to access the file?
questions.explanation: File URLs are permanent but require authentication/authorization.

questions.text: GRI needs to extract the "Text" from a PDF stored in Snowflake. How can they achieve this natively?

options.label: B
options.text: Using a Python UDF (Snowpark) with a library like PyPDF2.

questions.explanation: Snowflake unstructured data support allows you to use UDFs or Stored Procedures (Java/Python) to process files.

questions.text: When using an External Stage for unstructured data, how does the Directory Table stay in sync with the files in S3?

options.label: C
options.text: By setting AUTO\_REFRESH \= TRUE (via cloud notifications).

questions.explanation: You can manually refresh or automate it using event notifications from the cloud provider.

questions.text: Which function is used to retrieve the "Stage URL" for a specific file?
questions.explanation: This function generates a URL to a file in a stage.

questions.text: Does a Directory Table incur additional storage costs?

options.label: A
options.text: No, it is a free service.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it is billed as a very small amount of storage in a background table.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if the stage is internal.

questions.explanation: Directory tables have a small overhead for storing file metadata.

questions.text: GRI wants to grant a user the ability to see the files in a directory table but not the data inside the tables. What privilege is needed?
questions.explanation: You grant SELECT on the stage's directory table just like a regular table.

questions.text: Which of the following is a metadata column automatically provided by a Directory Table?
questions.explanation: Directory tables provide standard file metadata columns.

questions.text: Can GRI search for a specific PDF file name using a standard SQL WHERE clause on a Directory Table?

options.label: A
options.text: No, you must use the LIST command.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, Directory Tables can be queried using standard SQL.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if the files are indexed.

questions.explanation: This is the primary benefit of Directory Tables over the LIST command.

questions.text: A developer at GRI accidentally executes DROP TABLE TRANSACTIONS. Which command will restore the table and all its data immediately?
questions.explanation: UNDROP uses Time Travel metadata to restore dropped objects instantly.

questions.text: GRI is using the Snowflake Enterprise Edition. What is the maximum number of days they can configure for Time Travel on their permanent production tables?
questions.explanation: Enterprise Edition allows up to 90 days of Time Travel retention.

questions.text: GRI has a table that reached the end of its 90-day Time Travel period yesterday. Today, they realize they need to recover deleted data. Which feature applies now?
questions.explanation: Fail-safe is the 7-day period that automatically begins after the Time Travel window closes.

questions.text: Who can access and query data that is currently in the Fail-safe period?

options.label: D
options.text: Any user with the MONITOR privilege.

questions.explanation: Fail-safe is a system-recovery feature accessible only by Snowflake personnel.

questions.text: GRI wants to create a "Sandbox" environment for testing. They want to copy their 100 TB Production database without incurring additional storage costs or waiting hours for a data transfer. What should they use?
questions.explanation: Zero-copy cloning creates a metadata-based copy instantly with no initial storage cost.

questions.text: Which table types do NOT have a Fail-safe period?
questions.explanation: Transient and Temporary tables are designed for non-critical/session data and do not have Fail-safe to save on storage costs.

questions.text: GRI is replicating data from AWS US-East to Azure West-Europe. In the event of a regional AWS outage, which feature allows them to switch their secondary Azure database to "Primary" status?
questions.explanation: Failover (and Failback) is the process of switching the primary/secondary status of replicated databases.

questions.text: GRI updates a single row in a 10 GB table. How much storage is added to their Time Travel bill?

options.label: B
options.text: Only the size of the original micro-partition that was changed.

questions.explanation: Snowflake only stores the "changed" micro-partitions in Time Travel, not the entire table.

questions.text: Does Snowflake encrypt data at rest?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, but you must enable it in the ACCOUNTADMIN settings.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, all data is automatically encrypted by default using AES-256.

options.label: C
options.text: No, encryption is an add-on feature.

options.label: D
options.text: Only for the Business Critical edition.

questions.explanation: Snowflake provides transparent, automatic encryption at rest for all data.

questions.text: A GRI analyst wants to see what the Customers table looked like exactly 2 hours ago. Which syntax should they use?

options.label: B
options.text: SELECT \* FROM customers AS OF 2 HOURS AGO;

questions.explanation: The AT clause with OFFSET (in seconds) is the standard way to query historical data.

questions.text: GRI wants to share data with a partner company. The partner uses Snowflake. How is the data transferred to the partner?

options.label: C
options.text: The data is not transferred; the partner queries GRI's data directly via metadata sharing.

options.label: D
options.text: Using the PUT and GET commands.

questions.explanation: Secure Data Sharing is "zero-copy"; no data movement occurs.

questions.text: In a data sharing relationship, who pays for the storage of the shared data?

options.label: D
options.text: Snowflake provides shared storage for free.

questions.explanation: The provider always pays for the storage of the original data.

questions.text: GRI has a partner who does NOT have a Snowflake account but wants to query GRI's shared data. What should GRI create for them?

options.label: A
options.text: A new User in the GRI account.

questions.explanation: Reader Accounts allow non-Snowflake users to query shared data.

questions.text: Who pays for the compute (Virtual Warehouse) used by a Reader Account?

options.label: A
options.text: The user of the Reader Account.

options.label: B
options.text: The Provider (GRI) who created the Reader Account.

options.label: D
options.text: The SYSADMIN of the Consumer account.

questions.explanation: The provider account is billed for all compute credits consumed by the reader accounts they manage.

questions.text: GRI wants to share a dataset with the general public so any Snowflake user can find and use it. Where should they list it?
questions.explanation: The Snowflake Marketplace is the public platform for sharing and discovering data.

questions.text: GRI wants to share a table but hide certain columns like Profit\_Margin. What is the best practice?

options.label: A
options.text: Share the whole table and ask the partner not to look at that column.

options.label: B
options.text: Create a Secure View that excludes the sensitive column and share the view.

options.label: D
options.text: Clone the table, delete the column, and share the clone.

questions.explanation: Secure Views are required for sharing to prevent logic leaks and to control column visibility.

questions.text: A Consumer account wants to join a shared table from GRI with their own internal Inventory table. Can they do this?

options.label: A
options.text: No, shared tables cannot be joined with local tables.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, shared tables behave like local read-only tables.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they clone the shared table first.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if the ACCOUNTADMIN allows it.

questions.explanation: One of the main benefits of sharing is the ability to join shared "live" data with local data.

questions.text: Can a Consumer account perform an UPDATE command on a table shared by GRI?

options.label: B
options.text: No, all shared data is read-only for the consumer.

options.label: C
options.text: Only if they are given the OWNERSHIP privilege.

options.label: D
options.text: Only in the Business Critical edition.

questions.explanation: Shared data is strictly read-only for consumers.

questions.text: Which role is typically required to create a Share object?
questions.explanation: Creating a share is a high-level administrative task usually reserved for ACCOUNTADMIN.

questions.text: GRI wants to share data with a specific group of vetted enterprise partners in a private environment. Which feature should they use?
questions.explanation: A Data Exchange is a private, invitation-only data marketplace.
